B00006NSGX|5.0|I love this concert--(I have the DVD and the CD). I was also able to attend EC's Crossroads Guitar Festival in Dallas last year, and to hear him (and an unbelievable list of other greats). Billy Preston, who appears in 'One more car...' was there and showed himself to still be the master of the Hammond B3 (as he does here). Clapton was as astonishing in person in Dallas as he is on this DVD/CD. No one could ever accuse this multiple grammy award winner of being a one-hit wonder. For forty-plus years he has grown, experimented, responded to life, and in general evolved musically. On rare occasion he has gone places musically that I didn't particularly care to go with him, but we all grew from the experience, and he is, today, a consummate musician who doesn't have to live in his own (or anyone else's) past to have relevance. Critics who fault him for things like ending this concert with \\"Over the Rainbow\\" just don't get it musically. This song so belongs to another artist that, frankly, I don't expect anybody to be fool enough to cover it. Clapton carries it off beautifully, and makes it his own. This guy is not just a rock/blues guitar player. His musicality is too great to allow him to be pigeon-holed like that. At the Crossroads Festival, I saw him, within the same day, perform with B.B.King and Buddy Guy, Jeff Beck, and Carlos Santana. He sounded at home with everyone--and at times, he was pushing them musically, not just following them. Sadly, some people have such a narrow band of musical intellect, they can't tolerate musicianship that could stretch them if they would but let it. Pay no attention to the poor souls who long for Clapton to be who he was musically when they first were blown away by him. Buy this concert (I recommend the DVD for the visible interplay between the band members), open your ears and your mind, and experience a joyous, virtuostic performance by a man who doesn't need to cling to one style and who isn't afraid to still be a work in progress.
0312305060|1.0|I read this book a few years ago, after reading two of Cunningham's other, good novels, and all I could think of while reading this was \\"What, is this guy trying to win a Pulitzer or something?\\"  You see, every year at Christmas my best friend gets me a Pulitzer prize winning novel, and I read it.  With the exception of \\"Kavalier and Clay\\", which was excellent, the novels were all souless, bitter, poignant and oh-so-dramatic clunkers from hell.  They would employ obvious intertextuality with the \\"greats\\" of the past, showing \\"ordinary people\\" in the depths of their misery, grapling with suicide.  They revealed the hidden sorrow of these plain old folks and how, surprise-surprise, no one else knows they are deeply troubled.  These unhappy souls, as a matter of course, resort to chemical substances or a rich and eccentric fatasy world to soothe their over-the-top mental anguish.  These novels have a formula that combines Thoreau's adage about \\"men leading lives of quiet desperation\\" and the Rolling Stone's song \\"Mother's Little Helper\\" and keeps continuously repackaging these two bits of wisdom together to churn out what are themeatically the same novel over and over again.  It's hardly novel - it's simply a tragic retelling of the same tragic tale.  My impression was that these novels could all have been written by the same person, or by a group of writers trying to write as if they were the same person, like the ghost writers of the \\"Nancy Drew\\" or \\"Hardy Boys\\" series.    Cunningham's \\"The Hours\\" fits perfectly in with the other Pulizer Prize winners.  I did not actually THINK it would win a Pulitzer when I read it, it just seemed like the kind of novel that always wins.  I had assumed that  because his earlier novels had been either trashy or completely within the confines of \\"gay lit\\" that he wouldn't be considered.  But I guess the overwhelming similarity of this novel to the other previous winners was just so compelling that the judges could overlook Cunningham's earlier indiscretions and give out the award.  Maybe they thought his trying to be interesting and entertaining was just a phase, one that he has now grown out of, and he will now remain tastefully in the confines of that fine tradition of safely imitating classics that have already had the life sucked out of them by previous generations of writers and critics.    The sad thing about this novel is that the novels and people of a century ago that it is trying so hard to get in touch with were true outcasts in their time.  The crappy literature of the turn of the century, the stuff that won all the awards back then and the critics loved, is largely forgotten today because it was deriviative, pretentious crap that no one would want to read.  Instead, the stuff we love today from that era, like Virginia Woolf, was the same stuff your parents would have beaten you for reading back then.    No one's parents would be upset at your reading \\"The Hours\\" -you will be commended for your obvious good taste and depth of sensitivity.  Oh my, Virginia Woolf, I have no idea who she is but I just love her stuff!    I'm not saying we should only be reading novels that our parents would want to beat us for reading, but FOR GOD\\"S SAKE those are the novels we should be awarding Pulitzers to!    I know this reveiw will make some people a little angry, but I was very off-put by this book (well, obviously) and a lot of the reviews.  Especially, the theme I saw in a lot of the Amazon reviews was that \\"Virginia would be proud!\\"  I suspect Virginia would actually be all pissed off that a guy with obvious talent is wasting his time trying suck a few drops of blood out of her corpse instead of writing something daring and original.  Feel free to email me ([...]) with your ideas or hate mail, I am open to reunderstanding this book.

B0009A1AS2|4.0|I was one of the few who thought that Train of Thought was a masterpiece of metal.  It was heavy, loud, dark, and in your face.  I would have been perfectly fine if their next CD sounded like that, but fans complained, and DT is never a band that sticks with one style. <br /> <br />So what about Octaverium?  Well, the first time I heard it, I didn't really know what to make of it.  Most of the CD is much more poppy and radio-friendly than anything the band has released before, with the exception of Falling Into Infinity (my least favorite DT release.)  This CD is drivin more by Jordan Rudess than John Petrucci, which dissapoints me, I loved his wild solos on ToT.  'The Answer Lies Within' recalls Images and Words for me, which actually isn't a good thing.  You heard me right, I thought Images and Words was the cheesiest CD I have ever heard, and I hear that same thing creeping through my speakers when I listen to this song. <br /> <br />'I Walk Beside You' is also pretty lame, but not as bad as TALW.  I actually enjoy the lyrics here, and they manage to be poppy and uplifting without sounding like a self-help book. <br /> <br />The two songs that recall ToT ('The Root of All Evil', 'Panic Attack') absolutely blew me away.  Heavy, menacing, and fast, these songs really are what I think DT should sound like more often.  I suppose I can still get my fix of heaviness with 'Awake' and 'ToT.' <br /> <br />'These Walls' is also definately one of the better ones on here.  AWESOME keyboards, AWESOME lyrics, and emotion that doesn't sound made-up.  It's actually catchy, without sounding like something that would make it to radio anytime soon.  It would be cool if it did, though. <br /> <br />I have mixed feelings about 'Never Enough' and 'Sacrificed Sons.'  Both are fairly boring until those crazy insturmental sections kick in about halfway through.  I think they just need some time to grow on me, because they are not bad by any means.  I've heard the lyrics to 'Never Enough'have to do with how Mike Portnoy feels about his fan's constant complaints about the band's changing sounds.  Either way, the lyrics are pretty harsh.  'Sacrificed Sons' is about the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, and as good as LaBrie sounds on this track, I can't help thinking \\"A few years late, guys!\\" <br /> <br />Now, the final track, 'Octavarium.'  This is the longest single track the band has done to date, and it's quite good.  After a long intro, an orchastal section kicks in, and it just sounds fantastic.  The middle section of the song sags a bit if you listen closely, you can really hear some nice keyboard work by Jordan Rudess.  The song picks up pace again in the 4th movement, with LaBrie stringing together random cultural phrases and icons.  It gets even better in the finale, with screams of \\"TRAPPED INSIDE THIS OCTAVARIUM!\\"  AWESOME climax!  The song then slows down a bit and glides into the end, exactly 24 minutes after it began. <br /> <br />So, in summary, this is definately a good album by DT, and a good started for someone new, because it's a bit more poppy than the others.  It's no 'Scenes From a Memory', 'Awake', or 'Train of Thought', but it is definately a worthy addition to any fan's catalog. <br /> <br />Great Songs: <br />The Root of All Evil <br />These Walls <br />Panic Attack <br /> <br />Good Songs: <br />Never Enough <br />Sacrificed Sons <br />Octavarium <br /> <br />OK Songs: <br />The Answer Lies Within <br />I Walk Beside You <br /> <br />My ranking of DT's CDs: <br />1. Scenes From a Memory <br />2. Train of Thought <br />3. Awake <br />4. Octavarium <br />5. Six Degrees of Inner Turbulance <br />6. Images and Words <br />7. When Dream and Day Unite <br />8. Falling Into Infinity

B00009L1UP|4.0|Empire was my first exposure to this band. I was 16 and a typical teenager of the time but did not care for much of the Bon Jovi, Poison, and Warrant CRAP music which was ruling the airwaves. Queensryche offered something different. Intelligent lyrics, great intricate guitar work, a powerful rythm section and a vocalist who has a voice as distintive as a fingerprint. Resistance, Silent Lucidity, Empire, and Anybody Listening were then and are today still great pieces of music. Silent Lucidity really is Queensryche's best song taking a clear Pink Floyd influence and making it distinctive and truly their own.  <br /> <br />I admit  some of the songs sound a little too 80's generic love/relationship songs like Hand on Heart, The Thin Line, and Jet City Woman the latter having great Zeppelin style guitar in the begining of the song. Only One is a love song of the era but saved by great dual guitar work from Chris DeGarmo and Michael Wilton. Empire proved to be Queensryche's most mainstream album while keeping the classic Queensryche sound they found on Rage for Order and kept through the very dark and beautiful Promised Land. Empire truly is a great even though not quite classic album form a band that in 1990 was at the top of their game comming off their masterpiece landmark  album Operation Mindcrime.  <br /> <br />In conclusion Queensryche has always I think been just fine with the notion of being different from the typical norms of Hard Rock, Heavy Metal, Alternative, and Pop Rock and while critics and many of their loyal fans seem divided about their albums they have continued to make music with emotional depth and a musical quality which will always have a loyal even if thin fan base. I do think the loss of the unique Queensryche sound on albums like Rage, Mindcrime, Empire, and Promised Land did hurt them with fans and critics however their latter work still has some good material and flashes of true brilliance. Empire is definately worth a purchase.
B0000028UK|5.0|Pearl Jams much anticipated sophomore release was extremely popular, breaking records for fastest selling albums in a day, and week all over the world.  Why it is looked down upon by critics remains a mystery to me.  This is the best place to start if you're new to Pearl Jam, giving you some of the harder, grunge sounding songs (Go, Animal, Leash), and some of the softer sounds that would later define their career (Daughter, Elderly Woman, Indifference). <br /> <br />Honestly, the only track that I would EVER skip over on this album is Blood.  Vedders' lyrics and vocals are as passionate as they would ever be, Lashing out against the record industry (Animal, Blood, Leash), covering Social and Racial issues (W.M.A., Daughter), and stories about his own life (Rearviewmirror, Elderly Woman). <br /> <br />This album is the defining moment of Pearl Jams career (well, along with Vitalogy and No Code), where they expand their songwriting, showing that they shouldn't have been placed in the very vague \\"Grunge\\" genre, and begin to speak out against the music poseurs (whom Eddie knows as the fans who were just into them for Ten) and against the media. <br /> <br />This is my second favorite album from Pearl Jam (first is No Code), who also happens to be my favorite band. Easily one of the best albums of the 90's.  I assure that upon picking it up, you will not be disappointed. Enjoy.

B000002BFZ|5.0|Pearl Jams fourth studio album might be the least accessible of them all, but I, and many other Pearl Jam fans consider it to be their very best. Vedder and bandmates were seemingly off in their own world for Vitalogy and No Code, providing us with something totally new and unexpected. Vedder shines on this album, not in a vocal way, as in other albums, but his beautiful lyricism and songwriting were at a peak. Incorporating his Eastern influences, he once again brushes off all of the media and mainstream attention they had early on. Touche. <br /> <br />Jack Irons is added to Pearl Jams' ensemble on this album, replacing Abruzzese (sp?) on drums. He is excellent, the drumming on Hail Hail, Who You Are, and In My Tree is near perfection. Once again, Vedders lyrics are based upon all the struggles he faced as a child and during adolescence.  Lyrics in the songs Off He Goes, In My Tree, Sometimes, and Present Tense paint a vivid picture of his emotions. By listening to Smile you can get a sense of how much of an influence Neil Young had been on them (they worked with him on and album, and Neil played guitar on \\"I Got ID\\"(great song)). McCreadys' guitar work on Red Mosquito reminds you just how badly the man can tear up the geetar (in a good way ;). In Off He Goes, Vedder preaches the story of a man (supposedly himself) struggling to fit in and find his own. It is, without a doubt, one of the finest songs Pearl Jam has ever Produced. Lukin is a punk song, in which Vedder must have gone hoarse. Mankind and I'm Open are the weakest off the album. The first hardly sounding like a Pearl Jam song (I think Gossard sings), and the second with Vedder reading some strange poetry over music (The song I'm Still Here, which is very rare, shows Vedder putting this affect to a much greater use).  The album closes off with Around the Bend, a beautiful song where nothing is rushed.  Very good song to lay down to sleep while listening to. <br /> <br />This album is way to underappreciated for everyones own good (I think it has been the worst selling Pearl Jam albums so far). Probally not the best place to start if you're new to Pearl Jam, but anyone who is a fan of 90's alternative rock should enjoy this fine output from Pearl Jam. <br />
0060934913|5.0|a book you must read before your next dining out. scary, funny and pervaded with a deep love for food.
0684803356|5.0|Set during the Spanish Civil War, Ernest Hemingway's \\"For Whom the Bell Tolls\\" tells the story of Robert Jordan, a young American who is serving as a demolitions expert for the Republican cause.  The novel follows his experiences with a band of guerrilla fighters as he undertakes a mission to blow up a strategic bridge.  The whole novel, except for some flashbacks and reminiscences of various characters, covers just a few days.<br /><br />Although the novel focuses on a small number of characters in a fairly compressed time period, Hemingway attains a real epic feel with this book.  The novel is fairly lengthy (471 pages in the 2003 Scribner edition), but I found it to be a swift read--indeed, often difficult to put down.  There is much that is noteworthy about this novel.  It offers a compelling perspective on war from the viewpoint of guerrilla forces, rather than conventional forces (interested readers might want to check out Mao Tse-Tung's \\"On Guerrilla Warfare\\" for some theoretical and historical perspective).  The novel also deals with the phenomenon of ideologically committed foreign forces in Spain's Fascist-versus-Republican conflict.<br /><br />Hemingway deals with the issues of love and sex in a combat zone, as well as with the roles of women in a guerrilla force.  Other significant issues include loyalty, leadership, communications, military hardware, the impact of weather and terrain, and the connection between guerrilla and conventional forces.  Particularly interesting is Hemingway's portrait of Robert Jordan as a technically and tactically skilled guerrilla fighter, and as a leader of guerrilla fighters.  Thus the book should interest not just lovers of literature, but also serious military professionals and students of the history of warfare.<br /><br />Hemingway offers a grim and graphic look at the brutality of 20th century warfare.  War is not glamorized or sanitized, and atrocities are described in unflinching detail.  The characters explore the ethics of killing in war.  As the story progresses, Hemingway skillfully peels back the layers of Jordan and other characters to reveal their psychological wounds.  But the book is not all about pain and violence.  In the midst of war Hemingway finds the joy and beauty that keep his characters going.  He also incorporates storytelling as a powerful motif in the book; his characters share stories with each other, recall missing untold stories, or resist a story too hard to bear.  In Hemingway's world storytelling is as essential a human activity as eating, fighting, and lovemaking.<br /><br />Hemingway's writing appeals to all the senses as he creates some vivid scenes.  He demonstrates his mastery of the art of fiction; he continually makes interesting choices and creates some really striking and beautiful passages.  \\"For Whom the Bell Tolls\\" is an exceptionally haunting work of literature; I consider this rich and rewarding text to be an essential volume in the canon of war fiction.  For intriguing companion texts that also deal with the Spanish Civil War, I recommend \\"Spain's Cause Was Mine: A Memoir of an American Medic in the Spanish Civil War,\\" by Hank Rubin, and \\"The Confessions of Senora Francesca Navarro and Other Stories,\\" by Natalie L. M. Petesch.ethics of killing in war.  As the story progresses, Hemingway skillfully peels back the layers of Jordan and other characters to reveal their psychological wounds.  But the book is not all about pain and violence.  In the midst of war Hemingway finds the joy and beauty that keep his characters going.  He also incorporates storytelling as a powerful motif in the book; his characters share stories with each other, recall missing untold stories, or resist a story too hard to bear.  In Hemingway's world storytelling is as essential a human activity as eating, fighting, and lovemaking.<br /><br />Hemingway's writing appeals to all the senses as he creates some vivid scenes.  He demonstrates his mastery of the art of fiction; he continually makes interesting choices and creates some really striking and beautiful passages.  \\"For Whom the Bell Tolls\\" is an exceptionally haunting work of literature; I consider this rich and rewarding text to be an essential volume in the canon of war fiction.  For intriguing companion texts that also deal with the Spanish Civil War, I recommend \\"Spain's Cause Was Mine: A Memoir of an American Medic in the Spanish Civil War,\\" by Hank Rubin, and \\"The Confessions of Senora Francesca Navarro and Other Stories,\\" by Natalie L. M. Petesch.

They sound like something from somebody's 1975 home electronic organ with rhythm selection. On the other hand, her version of \\"Maybe You'll Be There\\" is to die for. Myung's bass licks in the first cut are unbelievable too. Blind Faith is pretty good, Misunderstood is great, but the cut that makes Disc 1 is The Great Debate. The song is well written, well produced and well thought out. I love how it makes such a bold political statement about Stem-Cell research and clips of people's opinions on the issue are played in the background of the band's intense building intro and fading, tapering ending. The second disc is the reason to buy this album though. To call the work Six Degree's of Inner Turbulence a song would be insulting to Dream Theater. The piece is a Magnum Opus taking up the entirety of the second disc and running at about 45 minutes. The 8 movement suite is staggering. The writting is incredible, the elasticity of the piece is infinite, and the story that it tells is incredible. The piece is dynamic on every level, themes are recalled and embellished throughout and the way the piece fits together as one entity is astonishing. All the solo work in the piece is also amazing. This album is a must have for any Dream Theater fan. Buy it!!!

B00003CXXP|4.0|I am not one to join these general online forums.  It has to be something very compelling or meaningful for me to break this rule of thumb.  So it was that I joined Amazon membership primarily to write a cathartic commentary and critique about this amazing movie, A.I.. <br /> <br />I had seen this movie in the theater when it was first released in 2001 because, unlike the rest of the pure garbage we get from Hollywood, it looked precisely like the kind of complex movie for which it is worth risking $9 of my already wrongly heavily taxed money.  I admit that I did not grasp fully back then the sophistication of the movie's message.  It just hit me like a sledgehammer 4 years later in August of 2005, some days ago, when I saw it for a second time. <br /> <br />I say my writing here is cathartic because my parents divorced when I was a boy of 8.  My mother left our family.  It fostered and strengthened in me resentments against her throughout my life that I had not realized were tearing me apart underneath miles-deep layers of denial or distraction. <br /> <br />We spent the overwhelming majority of the last 10 years without speaking to each other.  I could not understand how she, as the mature adult, could not make a stronger effort to stay in touch no matter what angry words I fired at her, especially because it was her decision that brought me into this world.  My anger would have eventually subsided if only she had tried a bit harder as the adult above my desire as a rebellious, rude teenager to be alone during her visiting rights.  I wish she could understand that it had far more to do with wanting autonomy at that stage in my life than rejecting her. <br /> <br />Her apparent indifference only reinforced my resolve.  Out of principle for how I would never treat my own child, I had even resigned and prepared myself psychologically to accept that she was dead to me even though this, even now, is not the case. <br /> <br />This movie forced me to a crossroads that Ihad not expected.  While I still carry this justified resentment, I feel terrible that I feel it for my own mother who--of all people--I wish could understand how very real and distinct was my disillusionment over her departure and how she could have mitigated it.  Even this last reflection causes me great distress as I type it. <br /> <br />I offer this background to illustrate that our reactions to this movie, A.I., will definitely be influenced heavily by what experiences we have had in our lives. <br /> <br />I gave this movie 4 stars out of 5 to acknowledge the valid criticism about its incontinuity of mood and plausibility during the middle.  It is true that the movie took an annoying departure from the up-'til-then superbly dramatic mood it had set in its first third.  It is true that Spielberg could have made the fictional \\"orga\\" society that disparaged \\"mecha's\\" a bit more realistic and less flashy as he had done so well in the first third.  It is true that the second third lingered a bit too long in this detour.  But even this section had its saving graces.  This section was indispensible for the message of the movie to depict the lopsided, even unwarranted conflict between two different groups and how not everyone on either side was as dumb or shallow as they seemed.  In fact, the reaction to this movie itself indicates on what side of the conflict's fence the viewer would likely have fallen had he been written into its script! <br /> <br />This critique aside, the final third of the movie fully recaptured and surpassed the mood it had previously lost, in time to matter.  It happened at about the point where David set out to meet his creator accompanied by Gigolo Joe who tried giving David some lessons in the ways of the world in a way that earlier his adoptive mother admitted too late she wished she had done at the moment when she forever abandoned her adopted son in the woods.   <br /> <br />I found Frances O'Connor's portrayal of Monica, David's adopting mother, to be truly disturbing and right on the mark.  She was a woman capable of despair, callous calculation and soft, loving sweetness all in the same movie.  Haley Joel Osment was exceptionally brilliant as her son and main character, David, for reasons you really must see for yourself.  Though Jude Law's character, the experienced Gigolo Joe, was dramatically certainly nothing out of this world, he was the \\"voice\\" of the necessary additional dimension so critical to making the viewer seriously reevaluate the parameters of what we, as humans, have considered \\"human\\" up 'til now.  How could \\"real\\" humans be so capable of destroying beings who(?) had evolved into emotional \\"parity\\" as demonstrated through their capacity for fear, pain and love?  Again, what does this say about the critics who \\"didn't connect\\" with David merely because he was \\"not real\\"?  Have they no capability to adapt a protocol to conditions that will minimize suffering in other entities?  The very way I ask that question is intentionally robotic. <br /> <br />Here was a boy who, whether by programming or not, had nothing but pure affection and enthusiasm for his adopting mother.  He would have achieved happiness only to hear her say that she loved him.  His mother, on the other hand, truly did not understand the nature of what she was unleashing when she decided to speak the words that would encode David's affection solely for her forever, even long after she was dead.  The foreboding question's prediction came to pass when David's creator was asked something to the effect of, \\"It's not whether artificial creations can love humans but if humans are capable of loving them back.\\" <br /> <br />Had the movie ended with David trapped in his hover copter with \\"Teddy\\" and that longing stare at the Blue Fairy, I would have been greatly disappointed that it really went nowhere. <br /> <br />In fact, the movie's message was NOT complete, in my view, UNTIL the element of far-future time was introduced, and WITHOUT descriptive text at the bottom of the screen.  It was NOT complete until we saw future \\"mecha's\\", who obviously outlived all the \\"orga's\\", rescue David from his icy grave and, thanks to extremely advanced technology AND human(?) compassion, were able to give him, whether real or not, what he had single-mindedly sought his entire life, even if only for one brief moment in his indefinite existence. <br /> <br />Stop reading now.  The next two paragraphs will spoil the dramatic end for you if you want to give the movie the chance to show you instead of reading about it through my words here. <br /> <br />The end began its crescendo of sadness when Monica and David interacted throughout this entire single day like never before in literally thousands of years, even though David understood that it would end by nightfall as his rescuers had warned him. <br /> <br />This crescendo of tears reached its peak as we saw a smiling David holding his never-to-be-woken-again mother's hand on the bed while ultra-brilliant composer John Williams's piece \\"Where Dreams Are Born\\" interlaced with Barbara Bonney's sweetly melancholy lyricless voice played as the camera receded from their peaceful scene, and the lights dimmed one by one from each room of the house. <br /> <br />This movie was a love story, though not at all the kind most would suspect.  It had, by far, the most unforgettable, gut-wrenching ending I have ever seen in my life.  I still have flashback pangs of sad reflection days after watching it.  I think Stanley Kubrick would have been proud of what Speilberg did by taking his creation in an equally or MORE interesting direction. <br /> <br />Having said all of this, I close by highly recommending this movie to anyone with a brain but, more importantly, a heart and a little patience. <br /> <br />As for me, I will send this critique to my mother in the hope that it will make permanent reconciliation a likelier possibility.

0618001905|5.0|Many of us who have read Joseph Conrad's \\"Heart of Darkness\\" think of it as an allegory tinged with racism--a tale of a European, Kurtz, who has abandoned the restraints of civilization and has surrendered himself to the barbaric despotism and primitive rituals innate to Africa. Yet Hochschild spends a full chapter of his excellent history reminding us of the novel's historical context: the figure of Kurtz is based on at least one real-life colonial administrator, and the barbarity is not one that is indigenous to Africa but imported from Europe. Conrad's contemporary readers understood that his novel was a condemnation more of colonial tyranny rather than of African primitivism.<br /><br />And the ringleader of these gang of hoodlums who invaded the Congo and massacred its inhabitants was King Leopold II of Belgium. In a tour de force of characterization, Hochschild  portrays Leopold as a petulant and greedy monster who decided at a young age that the way to wealth was ownership of an African colony and the subjugation of its inhabitants. Leopold initially made his profits through the exportation of ivory, but his bureaucrats struck gold with the expansion of the international rubber market.<br /><br />The victims were the natives, who lost not only their land and their freedom, but often their lives. There is no pretty way for Hochschild to tell this story: Leopold's officials used unbelievably harsh methods to force the locals to collect rubber--all in the name of bringing them European civilization, Christian charity, and a Western work ethic. In addition to taking wives and children hostage (in subhuman conditions) until the men made their quotas, soldiers would torture or kill the inhabitants if they faltered. One of the most grisly aspects of this calculatingly orchestrated version of modern slavery was the severing of hands--and their collection into baskets as proof of killings--as a means of terrorizing the population. The wonder of it all is that Leopold and his agents managed to keep most of these deeds secret and even disguised his colony as a charity for the benefit of \\"pagan\\" African natives.<br /><br />Yet Hochschild's narrative is not simply a gruesome account of the horrors of Leopold's personal fiefdom--which the king himself never once visited. The most fascinating part of this tale is the creation of what might reasonably be called the world's first human rights movement. George Washington Williams, the first and perhaps bravest campaigner, initially sounded the alarm, but he was ignored largely because he was African American. Later rabble-rousers had better success: E. D. Morel, whose suspicions were aroused when he noticed the imbalance of trade to the colony while working at the docks; William Sheppard, a Presbyterian missionary who provided first-hand accounts; and Roger Casement, a British consul who became an important anti-Leopold activist (and who later became an significant figure in the Irish independence movement whose closeted homosexuality provides a sad coda to his life's story).<br /><br />One of Hochschild's themes is astonishment, only a century later, at the world's amnesia (including his own) regarding these atrocities. Even the thousands of annual visitors to Laeken's Royal Greenhouses and Winter Palace, Leopold's extravagant and luxurious monument, do not realize that this park was literally built with the lives of millions of Africans. Fortunately, thanks to Hochschild's best-selling book, as well as similar reassessments published by European historians during the last twenty years, even the briefest biographical accounts about King Leopold II now portray him as he was: a brutal and gluttonous colonial thug.eopold and his agents managed to keep most of these deeds secret and even disguised his colony as a charity for the benefit of \\"pagan\\" African natives. <br /> <br />Yet Hochschild's narrative is not simply a gruesome account of the horrors of Leopold's personal fiefdom--which the king himself never once visited. The most fascinating part of this tale is the creation of what might reasonably be called the world's first human rights movement. George Washington Williams, the first and perhaps bravest campaigner, initially sounded the alarm, but he was ignored largely because he was African American. Later rabble-rousers had better success: E. D. Morel, whose suspicions were aroused when he noticed the imbalance of trade to the colony while working at the docks; William Sheppard, a Presbyterian missionary who provided first-hand accounts; and Roger Casement, a British consul who became an important anti-Leopold activist (and who later became an significant figure in the Irish independence movement whose closeted homosexuality provides a sad coda to his life's story). <br /> <br />One of Hochschild's themes is astonishment, only a century later, at the world's amnesia (including his own) regarding these atrocities. Even the thousands of annual visitors to Laeken's Royal Greenhouses and Winter Palace, Leopold's extravagant and luxurious monument, do not realize that this park was literally built with the lives of millions of Africans. Fortunately, thanks to Hochschild's best-selling book, as well as similar reassessments published by European historians during the last twenty years, even the briefest biographical accounts about King Leopold II now portray him as he was: a brutal and gluttonous colonial thug.

B000002TQV|4.0|I was looking through the reviews to see what others had to say about The Bends, most seemed very credible, until I got to some guy saying 'This isn't real music, real music is Led Zeppelin, Nirvana, (the usual), etc. I can't understand why certain people are unable to appreciate new music as well as old rock and roll and blues etc. I hold my Howlin' Wolf and Taji Mahal records in the highest regard, yet I can still enjoy Brian Eno or U2 or Talking Heads. I'm sure most true music lovers could say the same. There is no such thing as 'fake' music. There are 'fake' artists, but in the end, all musical judgement is a matter of opinion, I suppose. Well, I like The Bends. Personally, I find a lot more in Kid A and Amnesiac, but I am 100% certain the majority would disagree. I respect that. The Bends is full of well-written, memorable songs. It's quite accesible. (Nice Dream) and Bulletproof are too of my favourites, and I love Bones. It's electrifying. All the singles are classics, too. Some parts are lacking in something, but I don't know what. The one part that makes me cringe for some reason is that bridge in the title track with the 'I wish it was the sixties' lines. I dunno, it's just a very un-Radiohead breakdown, in my opinion. I would definitly recommend this album. High & Dry and Fake Plastic Trees are songs you will probably adore. It's an original rock album and there aren't many of those, so cherish it. It proves that Radiohead could push the bounderies of popular music even without drum machines and samplers. So, check this out. If you dig it, go through each of the following albums in order of their release, for their sound becomes more of an acquired taste as they progress. The one album to avoid is Pablo Honey. Although it does document their musical origin, it does not rank alongside any of their later works. So, I personally hope you will soon be listening to and enjoying Kid A and Hail To The Thief, but for now, start with this.

B0006957SA|5.0|Take a poet and songwriter like Shane MacGowan, give him seven top-class musicians, three bottles of Powers and a few thousand fags - what could go wrong? Nothing, that's what. Before this The Pogues had already went through two great eras - the early punk 'let's get pissed' era that spawned 'Red Roses For Me' (1984) and the sloppy fantastic drunken youthful coming of age that produced 'Rum, Sodomy & The Lash' (1985). What the band lost after this was Cait O'Riordan, who was a very powerful part of the bands style and image. So then, what they did, was become professional. They became great, so to speak. If I Should Fall From Grace With God is a masterpiece, in the non-pretentious meaning of the word. It is a piece by a band who have mastered their sound. MacGowans voice was at its peak - a raspy lived-in beautiful... thing. Look at the classic soon-to-be standards he wrote on this - Lullaby Of London, The Broad Majestic Shannon, Fairytale Of New York... . The covers are magnificently performed. Birmingham Six is defined, as is Galway Races. Fiesta is a great party tune as well. The playing is something else, it wipes the floor with their older performances, technically anyways (some may prefer the punky bash of old). But enough of the deep observant writing... Above all this a great album to crack open a can or pop a bottle and sing along and learn the words so you can carry these songs with you and sing them in pubs until your dying day. 'Let me go boys, let me go boys, let me go down in the mud where the rivers all run dry'.

B000002GY9|4.0|Sometimes Tom Wait's 70's stuff sounds something like if you read Jack Kerouac over Kind Of Blue-era Miles Davis. If that's not enough to tempt you, he also has ballads that are musically rich, lyrically depthful and heartbreakingly beautiful all at once. Small Change is probably the most all-round example of this. If you want extremes, buy Nighthawks At The Diner for the former and Blue Valentine for the latter. Lot's of these tunes are already the stuff of legend - Tom Traubert's Blues, the title track, I Can't Wait To Get Off Work - but a lot of the gems on this you probably haven't heard of. I Wish I Was In New Orleans is perfection, no other word for it. Some may call this music too maudlin, too schmaltz - including Waits himself - but if you ignore the cynic inside of you, what you'll find is something that's not like any other record out there. There is no such thing as a bad Tom Waits record, and I'm not usually one to make such fanatic claims. Nowadays he's doing this great, mysterious, musically challenging and innovative thing. In the 80's he was mutating his 70's work into something very unique and magic indeed. In the 70's he was making music that made his world yours, completely sensational. Every song on Small Change is like a novel, every note is like gold. Listen to Invitation To The Blues, Bad Liver & A Broken Heart, Step Right Up - from ballads to beat, this guy is a heavyweight. Always has been, always will be.

B000002GQH|4.0|That is, I'm not going to give this \\"core 7\\" Moodies outing 5 stars despite the fact that I use one of their best songs as my reviewer tag.  It's simply not as good as the others, and that is that.  Still, it yields good enough things to make it a solid 4.<br /><br />It is interesting that this album opens so onimously with an individual being challenged by the establishment which means to asphyxiate the belief that any one person is capable of thinking for themselves, and even more remarkable that our computerized society fits this mini-dialogue with such clairvoyant fruition over 35 years later.  In spite of some bright tunes on this album, there is also enough negative aura off the opening to affect most everything else on this album unless you play the tracks in shuffle mode or skip a few.<br /><br />\\"Lovely to See You\\" is indeed an odd sort of segue from that intro, but it's a great, positive Justin Hayward song that almost seems to be saying you will need to return to this song after your journey with this album is through.  By itself, this is a good rocker and one of the songs buying Threshold dignifies.<br /><br />\\"Dear Diary\\" is a rather creep-along, yet quietly whimsical contribution by Ray Thomas that sounds a bit as if it could fit onto Days of Future Passed.  The song almost contradicts itself in tone as he has a rather cavalier attitude about not being where he should have been, then begins to wonder what's happening to his indifference and wonderment at the blindness of others:  \\"It's over, will tomorrow be the same?  I know they're really not to blame.  If they weren't so blind then surely they'd see there's a much better way for them to be.\\"  What always strikes me is at the very end when he mentions \\"Somebody exploded an H-bomb today, but it wasn't anybody I knew...\\"  If nothing else about this song caught your attention, THAT will!<br /><br />Here's where we slip into some territory that weighs the validity of this album being a classic down.  I am convinced that the only reason this album is regarded as such is because it's part of the 7, and on its own the following tracks would leave it in the dust:  John Lodge's hippie country offering, oddly enough, while okay to listen to as a track is pathetically weak and should be left to somebody like the Monkees' Mike Nesmith who had a natural gift for that style of writing.  \\"To Share Our Love\\" is simply one horrible song that sounds like the band is singing one thing and John is yelling another song over them.  The word discordant comes to mind, and these are some of his worst contributions on any Moodies album that I can think of offhand.<br /><br />Mike Pinder is not to be outdone in the not-so-hot offerings either.  \\"So Deep Within You,\\" in spite of very good, direct lyrics and some of Mike's sharpest vocals, still manages to suffer from an ennui that's saved only by Ray Thomas's flute that's punctuated by Graeme Edge's percussion.<br /><br />By far the best songs on Threshold are Hayward's beautiful \\"Never Comes the Day,\\" a simple song about a couple that needs to try harder to take their love easier as they seem to have let life get in the way a bit--at least that's my interpretation--and Ray's \\"Lazy Day,\\" a sympathetic little tribute to the English mothers who make Sundays such a delight each week for their families.  Best of all, though, is Thomas and Hayward's \\"Are You Sitting Comfortably,\\" truly beautiful and uplifting in every way as it charms with its magical lyrics about Merlin and Camelot.  You are really able to lapse into a vivid daydream, except the song is too short!<br /><br />Pinder's little three-part opus, \\"Have You Heard 1 and 2 with  \\"The Voyage\\" in between, was so strange to my ears the first few times I played it that it took a long time to decide if I liked it at all.  I do understand that it ties the album together neatly when you go back to the introduction.  The song acknowledges that we share the same world, we are real and free.  Something of an answer to the establishment that would try and  mold us all into the same mindset.  By the time you come out of this track, however, and to the end of the journey, you are gasping for the air and sunshine that was semi-obscured by the initial tone set for this disc.  Herein also lies the problem with the album.  The concept is a bit choppy, so you are never quite sure with the lighter songs what the point is.  I guess that the point is to read into the lyrics yourself and interpret them your own way.  I feel this one is a bit all over the place in spots, but there are still enough great songs here to make this a valuable addition to your Moodies collection.  If anything, it will set your mind into a contemplative mode.e real and free.  Something of an answer to the establishment that would try and  mold us all into the same mindset. If anything, it will set your mind into a contemplative mode.

What the f*** are you thinking of!\\" At other times, it was like I was having a dialogue with the author. I felt as though I was there, in Mumbai, and that the characters were my friends and comrades. Like others, I'm at a loss for what to read next--nothing else really holds a candle next to this book.

B0006L16N8|5.0|We (the masses) are beginning to sift through music catalogues like we do through bad television-compliments of the Internet and good old file sharing software-and nowadays we are finding and listening to music that-up until ten years ago-would've taken a thrifty record store road trip to get hands on. That being said, we can literally find albums that tailor to our exact touch-which makes good mainstream rock sound like an evil profiteer. Granted, a majority of the mainstream music scene is in fact garbage. But what does any of this jargon have to do with Coldplay? Everything.    Coldplay are not innovators. They are not the experimental prowess that is the Mars Volta and Radiohead or pop revivalists (ala Oasis) on a mission to save music. They are a simple quartet who do a damn good job at writing cool, uncomplicated tunes-and occasionally getting their artless feet a little wet. Unfortunately, they were blown into bobble-headed, ironically iconic radio heroes.  The fact that we now have access to such an array of music makes it easy to compare and contrast. So what we have is a sea of people downplaying a powerful album in an anti-hype movement-and the few skeptics that do give it a chance listen to it with such muddled expectations that the whole disc rubs them wrong anyway.     So what about X & Y? The album is packed with fine cuts of music that demonstrate growing potential without being overly dramatic. Starting with \\"Square One\\"-a song that clearly draws inspiration from Radiohead and exhibits a slightly new direction for the band. \\"What If\\" is a standard ballad, but even at their most mundane, their songs make a lasting impression-like a Picasso. \\"Little White Shadows\\" is Coldplay's first synthesizer driven tune-and wait-we can actually tap our feet to this one. \\"Fix You\\" is the \\"Amsterdam\\" and \\"Higher Speed\\" of X & Y-definitely the standout track. By now we should all know that Chris lifted Kraftwerk's amazing \\"Computer Love\\" riff and made it \\"Talk.\\" So what-the song is eons from mocking our German friends of Kraftwerk and it doesn't sound cheesy. What about Rap-where classic songs are literally cut-n-pasted onto computer beats? For instance, I just heard one of Ray Charles' best songs from his Atlantic years layered into a hip-hop bonanza. I wonder who sold them the rights. In terms of ingenuity, \\"Swallowed in the Sea\\" isn't a breakthrough song. But it's one of those songs that can subliminally unify people-in a fun, nostalgic kind of way. \\"Twisted Logic\\" exploits the darker side of Coldplay and finds Chris Martin doing his best Space-Oddity era impression of David Bowie.    Martin uses melody unlike any artist in the industry-and that's not an opinion. He doesn't covet overboard super-hooks that become high school anthems or abuse the \\"what's right\\" pop formula as a safety blanket for success. Instead, he extracts melodies that are available and existent to us all--then turns them into beautiful-occasionally haunting-explosions of self-expression. But if you aren't into their sound or this style of music-then turn away. Too many people argue X & Y lacks passion, inpiration and ambition. Funny, since it empowers the patient  listener with just that.         \\"What If\\" Coldplay were riding the Indie-Rock tidal wave with Death Cab For Cutie? \\"What If\\" they took more chances like Radiohead did? \\"What If...?\\" Yeah, then they'd probably be more appealing to the critics, seem more adventurous to the cynics and play longer, more personable shows for the fans. But that's the nature of the big label business. So in the end, if this review conveys anything-it's to just take music for what it is, and not for what you'd prefer it to be. You're not jumping onto a \\"bandwagon\\" when you like music for what it is-especially if it's in the 90th percentile.

B00005JN5X|1.0|I knew in the first five minutes that this movie was going to disappoint me.  It took only another 45 for me to realize that it was more than disappointing, it was despicable.  I walked out and received a full refund immediately following the ridiculously non-sequitorious cat-puree scene.  But the things I noticed before that, which should have been a clue were:<br /><br />A) PACING: The movie goes by at such top speeds that you can never feel anything for any of the characters because they aren't on screen long enough to have any substance.  Finally I got tired of trying to keep up -- literally.  I fell asleep during a scene where I think they were fighting a wolf, and my friend had to nudge me awake.  There are flashbacks within flashbacks, for no reason at all.  This film was clearly edited by a pack of trained monkeys.<br /><br />B) SETS & COSTUMES: All look like sets and costumes.  Nothing is natural.  Everyone's clothes are perfectly shiny and clean and new, fresh from the costume warehouse.  The houses and storefronts are freshly painted and not even rain-damaged.  It all looks as fake as it is, which didn't help me get into the story either.<br /><br />C) ACTING: Flat or over-the-top, with absolutely no in-between.  I barely understood a word Peter Stormare said the entire time I was there.  And the sad part is that even when I didn't understand it, from the first line he had, I already didn't care.  Everyone else's lines seem out of context and rushed.  The accents are horrendous.  The movie's supposed to take place in Germany but Matt Damon sounds like a person faking a British accent.  His performance was heartbreaking; I truly thought Matt Damon could do no wrong.  But it was bad. 0596007124|5.0|This is the best introduction to design patterns I've seen.  The authors present each pattern in the context of a problem.  The \\"obvious\\" solution is considered first, and then its pros and cons are discussed.  The code is then redesigned to use a pattern, and the advantages of the new design are explained.  The entire book is very clear, and uses examples that are easy to understand. <br /> <br />This book doesn't cover as many patterns as the classic \\"gang-of-four\\" book, but readers who are getting their first look at design patterns will get much more out of it.

B00005JNEI|5.0|Yes, I liked _Farhenheit 9/11_, but that is not my point here. Rather, in respone to previous reviewers who stated that Moore is \\"un-American\\" and that he should be executed for \\"treason,\\" I would just like to say that one of the best ways to love your country is to care enough to criticize it when you think it is doing something wrong or being governed badly.  Dissent is an act of courage and responsible citizenship, not treason.  Furthermore, the exercise of our constitutional right to free speech is one of the most American activities a person can engage in. The accusation of \\"treason\\" by some of these reviewers reminds me of events during WWI, when many American citizens were held as prisoners of conscience, sentenced to years in prison because they dared to speak out against the war.  Eugene V. Debs was one such prisoner, sentenced to 10 years in  federal prison for giving a speech in which he criticized U.S. involvement in WWI. You can read this Canton, Ohio speech for yourself in _Eugene V. Debs Speaks_ by Jean Y. Tussey if you would like to know what the government was labeling sedition at that time. The Sedition Act prohibited any \\"profane or abusive language\\" against the United States government. No matter whether you're a liberal or a conservative, let's agree that we should not return to those days when in this supposedly free country a person could be imprisoned for stating his beliefs. That, my friends, was something truly un-American.

B00003CXCD|5.0|I saw this movie for the first time on TV, the show began at 1:30 in the mourning from sunday to monday and ended at 4:00 AM. Fortunately I won't have to do that again as that very monday after seeing it for the first time I ordered the DVD to watch it without TV ads. <br /> <br />This is classical cinema the way Hollywood used to make its movies: we have a great cast, a charming story, chemistry between Peck and Hepburn and one of the greatest endings ever made on a romantic comedy, all set in a beautiful city as Rome. <br /> <br />Hepburn is a princess who is sick and tired of his life style. She wants freedom, freedom to talk to normal people, to walk on the streets, to choose her haircut, freedom to live at least a few moments as she wants to (by the way, the mexican translation of the movie title is something like \\"The Princess that wanted to live life\\", wich summarize pretty much what this story is about). <br /> <br />She escapes from his country's embassy after she takes some medication to help her sleep and on the street she is found sleeping by Gregory Peck, who takes care of her. Peck is a journalist and when he sees on the newspaper the picture of the princess (who is supposed to be sick, according to the embassy) he will try to get an exclusive note on the princess during her juorney trough Rome. <br /> <br />We all know what's going to happen between them as this movie doesn't have the most innovative plot in history. What makes this a classic is the chemistry between Peck and Hepburn, the jokes (some of them silly) and the sense of joy seen on Hepburn as she discovers Rome, which makes more beliavable her character (she won the Oscar for that role). <br /> <br />As some user noted before, this movie has a little plot twist at the end. This is a coda, a perfect finale. We see a dream come true, but at the end all the characters wake up from their dreams and come back to reality. That's what sets Roman Holiday appart from other cinderella-like stories. I have seen better movies, but none of them is as enjoyable as Roman Holiday. Go and see it today if you haven't, and if you have then see it again every time you want to remember why do you love cinema. <br /> <br />Enjoy!!!!!!

0743454537|3.0|I admit that this story is compelling. It's a little more \\"best-sellerish\\" than my typical reading material, but I picked it up on a whim and then spent so much time reading it in the bookstore that I finally gave in and bought the darn thing.  <br /> <br />The writing is serviceable, but not masterful. My primary complaint in this regard is that Picoult told the story from too many different viewpoints (7, by my count), and the voice of each character was so similar that I often had to check the name at the beginning of the chapter to determine which character was speaking. Even Jesse's voice (perhaps the most recognizable in the bunch) was distinguished primarily by a peppering with the occasional curseword (which was completely appropriate to his character; I have no idea why it would have irritated anyone. Troubled eighteen-year-old boys don't have the same vocabularies as nuns. Had Jesse's character never cursed, it would have been astoundingly unrealistic.) Interestingly, I did find her male characters a bit more enjoyable to read than the females. <br /> <br />I thought there were credibility issues throughout. Sure, Anna's history may have made her wiser than the average thirteen-year- old, but there were multiple instances where I simply didn't buy her precocious voice as that of a rather socially isolated adolescent girl (Why, for instance, would she think of someone's name as sounding like \\"an overpriced bar drink\\"?? This child has clearly never been in a bar and would have no frame of reference for such a thought. This occurred within the first few pages of the book, and throughout the book, this type of flaw in the narration caused a troubling break in my suspension of disbelief.) <br /> <br />Also, I had trouble with the lawyer's \\"secret.\\" It didn't seem possible that he could have hidden it for so long. Wouldn't he have had to explain to someone, somewhere, why he needed to bring a service dog into the courtroom when he was clearly not blind or hearing impaired? Because I am familiar with this type of service dog, I knew immediately what his disability was. I found it hard to believe that nobody he'd encountered in the past fifteen years had similar knowledge. If Julia had really been curious about it, why didn't she just go online and google \\"service dogs\\"??? Silly. I liked the implications of Campbell's disability, but this aspect of the character and his storyline could have been made a little more believable with a little more effort on the author's part, I thought. <br /> <br />As others have mentioned, Sara's disregard for her other children is a little hard to swallow, though I didn't find it completely unbelievable given the circumstances. I did think that the psychology behind this dynamic could have been more fully illuminated. Was there, for instance, some reason that she identified with Kate more strongly than with her other children? <br /> <br />I had trouble with the resolution of the major plot, as well as that of the subplot between Julia and Campbell. The resolution of the latter seemed far too pat--like something that belonged in a romance novel, not a novel that purports to deal with supremely messy issues of life, death and medical ethics.   <br />Like other reviewers here, I did feel that the unexpected ending was a bit of a cop-out. I'd rather have seen the consequences of a more difficult decision by Anna and the others. This ending felt manipulative....ultimately, it just didn't ring true. I suddenly felt the author's hand manipulating her story, rather than a natural resolution to each of the characters' stories as they had unfolded thus far. Again, the break in suspension of disbelief. Also (and here I risk giving away a little too much), I felt the author's choice regarding the driver of the vehicle that plays a role in the plot twist was poor. It should have been Sara, I think.  <br /> <br />Despite the flaws that marred the flow of the story and its resolution, this was still an engrossing and highly readable book...it engaged me emotionally and of course led me to ponder some of the ethical issues presented in the work. I would recommend it, especially to young women, who might be more tolerant of the heavy doses of melodrama.  <br />

1400049628|5.0|While classed as \\"humor,\\" this book takes itself very seriously.  It adopts its own mythos to explain the possibility and periodic appearance of zombies and covers all manner of survival rules--from what kind of supplies to stockpile, where to hole up, what weapons work best against the shambling masses.  For the most part, I found it fascinating.  The least appeal for me was in the history of zombie attacks presented at the end.  My main pleasure was in considering Brooks' theories on why schools make good shelters and malls do not (not for the same reason Romero suggests) or why this weapon is superior to that one.  A lot of thought went into this, and reading it really fired my imagination.  If you enjoy \\"what if\\" scenarios, then you might enjoy this one, too--but don't come to it expecting slapstick just because it's in the humor section.  I'm easily amused, but only once or twice did this book inspire me to laugh out loud.  I am recommending it to my friends, but not without some caveats.

1400032717|5.0|When this book first came out, I dismissed it as a gimmicky work that would never stand the test of time.  After weeks and weeks on the best seller lists, however, I finally decided to see what was making this little red title fly off the shelves.  The book requires you to get past the somewhat implausible concept of a teenage autistic narrator named Christopher who writes with the simple precision of Hemingway.  Once you swallow the concept (and you will), this odd narrator leads you through a moving detective story in which he uncovers some troubling family secrets while investigating the mysterious death of his neighbor's dog.  This same story, told by an ordinary narrator, would be unremarkable.  But using his love of math as a way of parsing through life's ambiguities and anchoring himself in a chaotic world, Christopher alternately wows you with his insights into how mathematical laws explain complex subjects like human evolution and then breaks your heart with his inability to complete everyday tasks like boarding a train.  In the end, though, you may begin to question who is more balanced, the multitudes who carry on their lives without questioning what it's all about or this young autistic man who takes nothing for granted and lives true to his own logic-based code.<br /><br />-Kevin Joseph, author of \\"The Champion Maker\\"

She had superstar looks with her healthy curves that shattered the misconception that women in Hollywood had to be dangerously thin if they wanted to be known as attractive and wanted.  Her one strength was her dancing ability and her steaming hot videos and this compensated for her weak voice.  Yet Britney has ruined her physique and this was her best feature as an artist, because the majority of fans chose to look beyond her hopeless singing efforts .  She smokes drinks and sleeps around and is concerned with impending motherhood, so it looks as if the Britney that set the music world on fire with her every move is no longer the icon she once claimed to be.    This album shows Britney moving in the direction of dance music.  The bubblegum pop tracks she once released are no longer present on this album and it would be expected that Britney would take the opportunity to evolve into an entertainer with a little substance.  Her producers on this LP-who just happen to be some of the best in the recording industry (R Kelly) (P Diddy) (Moby) work overtime to conceal her limited vocal range and the infectious production work, which serves the purpose of distracting our attention away from the actual singing, highlights her inability to hold a note and project her voice in the tracks.  The openingtrack is a disater and this sets the tone for the rest of the album.  Madonna makes a cameo appearance but the meaningless lyrics and forgetable beat makes this one song that has no appeal and despite the common expectation that two of the most overrated stars could produce a record that is fairly exciting, this track disappoints.  The next five or more tracks all blur together and I have listened to the album six times I can't even recite the lyrics or hum the tune.  They talk about sex and sex and more sex and getting intoxicated which ironically are the issues that Britney is best known for in the present climate.  Toxic is the only track that is polished and produced ready for an assault on the music charts.  This is a highlight of her career and it does prove that with a little help from a good songwriter and producer Britney can create a unique and original sound.  The song Everytime could be quite an emotional record.  The beat is soft and the sound is easy to listen to which is in contrast to the background noise on the other tracks that has no structure and is a repetitve and mediocre mix of techno sounds.  But her voice is not strong enough to capture emotion.  In fact the whole album is a selection of whispers and panting.  Britney cannot sing and she is proving it with this album.

Hitchcock goes back to Daphne du Maurier for a third time (Jamacia Inn and Rebecca).  This was one of his best all out horror films (Only Psycho was better).     Most people know the story of the birds taking over a small coastal town in Northern California.  But Hitchcock sets a love story in the middle of it.    The film stars Rod Taylor and newcomer Tippi Hedren.  And features future stars Suzanne Plushette (Bob Newhart Show), a young Veronica Cartwright (Invasion of the Body Snatchers) and Jessica Tandy (Oscar winner for Driving Miss Daisy) as Rod Taylor's mother!    DVD EXTRAS:     About the Birds - 1 hour 19 minute documentary about the making of the film.  This is a comprehensive documentary about the making of the film with interviews his daughter Patricia, production designer Robert Boyle, writer Evan Hunter, F/X technicians Bill Taylor and Syd Dutton, makeup artist Howard Smit, storyboard artist Harold Michelson, stars Tippi Hedren, Rod Taylor and Veronica Cartwright and film historians Peter Bogdonvich and Robin Wood.   This may sound long but it is a wonderful look not only into the film but Hitchcock.    Deleted Scene - This is a scene that was shot but did not survive.  It contains stills and the script.     Original Ending - This was the original ending for the film.  It contains storyboards and the script    Storyboard Sequence - Hitchcock had the entire film in story board before it started filming.  This is 30 storyboards that show the attack on Marion at the end with the actual film still.    Tippi Hedren's Screen Test - This is her original screen test with Martin Balsam and background voice of Hitchcock.  It runs just under 10 minutes.  Screen tests are seldom seen and so this is fun to see.    \\"The Birds\\" is coming - 1 minute newsreel promoting The Birds and Tippi Hedren    Suspense Story - 2 minute newsreel on Hitchcock's appearance at the National Press Club.    Production Photos - 30 publicity photos    Production Notes - Notes about the film from Hitchcock    Cast and Filmmakers - Bios on Tippi, Rod, Suzanne Plushette, Jessica Tandy and Hitchcock

B00003CY5J|4.0|While I'm not going to tout THE SCORE as an Oscar-worthy masterpiece, it is certainly one of the best \\"heist\\" films that I have seen in a long time.  THE SCORE does everything right: it allows its incredibly talented acting performances to become the central focus of the movie and not the high-tech gadgetry that are the staple of cheaper thrillers.  To be sure, THE SCORE is not without technology, but what makes this film \\"pop\\" is the fact that we are drawn into the plot by De Niro, Brando, and the absolutely fantastic performance of Norton.  As in PRIMAL FEAR, Norton plays a split-role, doubling as both an overeager thief and a mentally-challenged night janitor (a role he adopts in order to gain access to the high-security facility).  His performance is, as always, very impressive and certainly above-par for \\"heist\\" films.<br /><br />While some have complained of the slow pacing, I did not find it slow at all.  In fact, I enjoyed the slow build-up.  The first time you watch this movie, you will be wondering to yourself: \\"How on earth are they going to get into that impenetrable safe?\\"  It will keep you guessing right up until the very end.  And just when you think you have a grip on the entire plot, it will twist on you.  I love it when films do that to you and THE SCORE does it in spades.  And the fact that the director has the patience to let the film build without going for cheap-thrills is a testament to his ability.<br /><br />Once again, I'm not arguing that THE SCORE is the best movie I've seen lately.  But it is very much an entertainig thriller that is worth a look.  You will enjoy the action, the effects, and all of the usual things one finds in a \\"heist\\" film.  But you will also be surprised by the good acting.  I highly recommend it.

This, however didn't disturb me, it is quite easy to skip past one sentence on the bottom of the page. They served their purpose well, in any case. Even without reading them, and with knowing that they are nonexistent, they managed to add a feeling off authenticity which allowed the reader (or say, a reader with an imagintion) to delve deeper yet into the events, and feel the weight of them, if they were to occur. <br /> <br />The entire principle of the book was extraordinary. It was exactly that it WASN'T your typical horror novel that made it so horrific. I hadn't even thought of using the word horror novel in application to this novel, until i read it in one of the other reviews here. 0553275976|5.0|Bonfire of the Vanities is a long book and a good story by celebrated author Thomas Wolfe.  I read a review of the book below and am wondering it it contained too much information and might have spoiled the ending, because right now I'm only halfway through the book.  So far, the sense I get is that there are no good guys or bad guys, but there is right and wrong and each character spends time flirting with both sides.  Sherman McCoy is a man who has all the trappings of success but his little empire is threatening to crumble becasue of his mounting debt, his affairs, and oh ya, a little hit and run accident that he should have reported to the police but didn't.  McCoy, as a character, doesn't have many redeeming qualities.  However, as political and cultural forces slowly unite to turn against him, I find myself rooting for him to stand up for all that is bad in society:  the tabloid press, the Jesse Jackson/Al Sharpton types that don't really care about the truth and the district attorneys looking for politcal gain.<br /><br />Wolfe covers every aspect of this hit run, from its innocent beginnings to the outlandish policical case that it will turn into.  Now 2/3rds of the way book, it seems Wolfe holds none of the characters in too much regard.  Everyone from the victim, the accuser, the lawyers and the press are pandering to their weakest traits.  I think that's where the title of the book comes from.  What happens when you throw a bunch of people looking out only for themselves into one volitile situation.  You get this book.<br /><br />Having now finished the book, I see why it is considered a classic.  Wolfe tells a great story.  Sherman McCoy is a bad man, motivated by money and seduced by younger women.  But when he gets involved in the accident, he slowly begins to change.  He is almost forced to change because all the other people involved in his life are worse than he is.  Yet they aren't behaving badly.  Wolfe just portrays these people for who they are.  Kramer is the district attorney who seizes the case against McCoy as a way to make a better life for himself.  He does what anyone else in the situation would do.  Reverend Bacon is typical of the race mongering civil rights activistis who put themselves above those they supposedly serve.  Peter Fallow is a journalist who would be nuts to refuse to cover a story that is given to him.<br /><br />I recommend this book because it points what can happen when selfishness overtakes people's lives.  And it is an entertaining story that shows what happens when liberal politicians put their own success ahead of the truth.are. B00008WJBU|4.0|Intacto is an interesting movie based on a very original and creative theme. It loosely based on the adage that states \\"there is limited luck in this world, you always get somebody else's share\\". The movie is about a bunch of people who are either full of luck or utterly luckless. The luckless hunt for the lucky ones, run wagers and attempt to get lucky themselves. The very idea of being able to collect luck is intriguing. <br />Samuel (Max von Sydow) is an old holocaust survivor who runs a high-end casino in the middle of nowhere. He has been extremely lucky all his life and plays a dangerous one bullet game. He hasn't lost in thirty years and all his challengers have died. Thomas Sanz (Leonardo Sbaraglia) is the lone survivor of a plane crash (and thus deemed lucky) who is approached by a luckless Federico (Eusebio Poncela) to run wagers. Federico  is deceitful and wants to steal some of Thomas's luck and Thomas wants to quickly multiply his aircraft-crash insurance compensation. Incidentally, Thomas had burgled a bank before the crash and a cop in the form of Sara (Monica Lopez) is in hot pursuit. Each character's life gets entwined while as they attempt to fulfill their motives. The story wavers and gets confusing at times, but that just adds to the  intriguing plot. Thomas eventually manages to run a wager with Samuel ... you'll have to watch the movie to know the winner. <br /> <br />Intacto is another good movie coming from Spain. Terrific performances by Leonardo Sbaraglia and Max von Sydow. The cinematography deserves high marks, it is successful in creating surreal landscapes. The wager games are very creative.

0060922583|2.0|The overwhelming 5-star reviews here (as well as the low 'helpful' votes for any Amazon review that claims this book is a sham) leads me to believe that this book is being read by a lot of fans of paranormal and new age literature. <br /> <br />The problem with a \\"true believer\\" is that any evidence they see that counters their beliefs are immediatley rejected, without even examining the facts. Just because something can't be explined by science does not automatically mean that the paranormal explination is correct. Worse yet, any subscriber to the holographic universe (which is just a form of solipsism--that reality is a construct of the mind) will give you the standard smug \\"you are unenlighted\\" defense, as if that proves anything.  <br /> <br />Another reviewer put it best, and I think that he needs to be re-quoted because he makes a valid argument against this book being taken seriously: <br /> <br />\\"Talbot, an excellent writer, begins with the work of Karl Pribram, who does research into how the mind stores and retrieves memories. At some point, Pribram became aware of holograms, and found that the way the refracted laser light of hologram construction spreads out on its way to the film reminded him of the way a nerve impulse fans out at the end of a neuron. This, apparently, was enough to convinve Pribram (and Talbot) that not only is memory holographic, but so is the entirety of existence merely a holographic construct created by our brains... <br /> <br />Whether or not these things really happen, the whole book is based on an untested hypothesis based on an analogy drawn by one researcher. Does the analogy stand up when examined? How does the refracted light projected onto a film have anything to do with signals passing between physical neurons? Talbot never asks. For me, the analogy falls apart as soon as I take one step past noticing a correlation between the two events. This is more than Talbot (or, apparently, Pribram) ever does at any point in his book, so great is his enthusiasm.\\"
B00006GO9Q|3.0|The title track is the sole masterpiece. Also, please be aware that the titles are mistitled. What you've got here is an ABA format wherein the first track is reprised at the end. IN A SILENT WAY/IT'S ABOUT THAT TIME should actually be listed as IN A SILENT WAY/IT'S ABOUT THAT TIME/IN A SILENT WAY. Likewise, SHHH/PEACEFUL should be listed as SHHH/PEACEFUL/SHHH.    IT'S ABOUT THAT TIME is an incredibly lame dud-track that should've been omitted. SHHH/PEACEFUL/SHHH are perfectly enjoyable hack-tracks whose appeal is based on instrumental texture rather than compositional content. In other words, what you've got here is all timbre and not much content. Wayne Shorter's low-key eloquence is just as enjoyable as the electric pianos. Miles's trumpet, however, is too overbearing during some of his passages. He's too loud during those hackneyed high-register passages.

Let me list some of the problems I found with the Extended Edition: <br /> <br />- First of all, no DTS soundtrack, which detracts a lot of value from any updated version of the film. The DTS track in the original DVD release was extraordinary, and it's difficult to understand why it is missing in this special edition. <br /> <br />- The new Dolby Digital mix included in this Extended Edition is problematic. The middle/center channel seems much lower than the rest, so the conversations are barely audible at times, yet fights and action scenes are very loud. None of these problems existed in the original DVD release: both DTS and Dolby mixes were properly balanced. Not in this version. I compared them side by side and couldn't understand why they had messed up the mix so badly in this super-duper edition. It's not worth your cash. <br /> <br />- The new edition of the film adds 17 minutes of footage that were left in the cutting floor. To tell you the truth, there's no compelling reason why those 17 minutes shouldn't remain in the cutting floor. These missing scenes really don't add much to the story, and hardly call for an \\"extended edition.\\" I was hoping they were going to include the much talked about fight of Maximus with a rhino. Forget it! The extra 17 minutes are mainly conversations building up the political conspiracy going on in Rome. <br /> <br />While some of the extra features are somewhat interesting, I found the Extended Edition to be a rip-off, and it hardly justifies the $29 they charge you for it. Stick to the original DVD, specially if you enjoy full-bodied DTS sound.
